briefing.headline: The Stolen Mountain Equipment Case
briefing.narrativeHtml:
Learning Targets for Today:

  • I can use a globe to locate the world's longest mountain range
  • I can explain how mountains affect weather and climate
  • I can research how people live and work in mountain areas
  • I can identify countries by looking at mountain shapes on maps
  • I can understand how geography affects where people build cities

Your Mission: Help Sourdough Pete track down Dr. Altiplano! She's been stealing special equipment from mountain research stations. She thinks she's helping the environment, but stealing is wrong! Follow the clues using your maps, globes, and research skills to find her mountain hideout.

What You'll Need: World globe, physical map showing mountains (brown areas), atlas, and internet for research

Detective Challenge: Dr. Altiplano loves really tall mountains and cold places. Can you follow her trail through 5 mountain clues?

suspects.name: Dr. Altiplano (Isabella Santos)
suspects.description: A scientist who loves studying mountains and cold places. She thinks stealing research equipment will help save the environment, but that doesn't make it right!

rounds.clueHtml:
Mountain Detective Clue #1:

Dr. Altiplano was spotted stealing equipment from a place with really tall, snowy mountains! Here's what we know:

  • She's hiding in the world's LONGEST mountain range - it goes for thousands of miles!
  • These mountains are so tall that it's hard to breathe at the top because the air is thin
  • The mountains look like a long, bumpy spine running down the side of a continent
  • When you look at a map, find the brown areas that show really tall mountains

Your job: Use your globe and maps to find the longest mountain range in the world!
researchPrompts: Look on your globe for the longest mountain range in the world
Find the brown areas on your physical map that show tall mountains
Research which mountain range is the longest on Earth
Look up why the air gets thin when you go up really high mountains
expectedProcess: Student spins globe looking for long mountain chains
Student examines physical map for brown mountain areas
Student identifies the Andes Mountains in South America
Student learns that mountains have thin air at the top

reveal.note: Expert at climbing in thin air

rounds.explainHtml:
Great detective work! You found the Andes Mountains!

The Andes are the longest mountain range in the world - they stretch for about 4,300 miles (that's like driving from New York to Alaska!). They run along the west side of South America like a giant rocky spine.

What You Learned:

  • Mountain ranges show up as brown areas on physical maps
  • The Andes Mountains are the longest mountain range on Earth
  • Air gets thinner as you go higher up mountains, making it harder to breathe
  • Mountain ranges can stretch across many different countries

rounds.clueHtml:
Mountain Detective Clue #2:

Dr. Altiplano is now stealing ice-drilling equipment! She's looking for old ice that's been frozen for thousands of years. Here's what we discovered:

  • She's at a place where ice never melts, even though it's near the equator!
  • The ice is so old that it has tiny air bubbles trapped inside from long, long ago
  • Scientists study this ice to learn what the weather was like before your grandparents' grandparents were born
  • These mountain glaciers are disappearing because the Earth is getting warmer

Your job: Find places in the mountains where ice stays frozen all year, even in warm countries!
researchPrompts: Look up mountain glaciers near the equator
Research how old ice tells us about ancient weather
Find pictures of glaciers in South American mountains
Look up why some mountain ice is melting
expectedProcess: Student researches tropical glaciers in the Andes
Student learns that old ice contains ancient weather information
Student discovers that mountain glaciers are melting
Student understands that high mountains can be cold even in warm places

reveal.trait: Studies old ice and ancient weather

rounds.explainHtml:
Excellent research! You found the tropical glaciers!

Even though Peru is close to the equator where it's usually hot, the mountains are so tall that they have glaciers! These are called 'tropical glaciers' - ice that never melts because the mountains are so high up where it's always cold.

What You Learned:

  • Very tall mountains can have ice and snow even in warm countries
  • Old ice contains tiny air bubbles that tell us about ancient weather
  • Scientists study glaciers to learn about climate change
  • Height matters more than location when it comes to staying cold

rounds.clueHtml:
Mountain Detective Clue #3:

Dr. Altiplano is now talking to local mountain people and learning their secrets! Here's what our spies saw:

  • She's visiting people who have lived in the mountains for hundreds and hundreds of years
  • These mountain people grow food on terraces - like giant steps cut into the mountainside
  • They know special tricks for growing crops way up high where the air is thin
  • They speak languages that are different from Spanish and have their own traditions

Your job: Research the people who live in the Andes Mountains and how they grow food on steep slopes!
researchPrompts: Look up how people farm on mountain terraces
Research the people who live in the Andes Mountains
Find pictures of step-like farms on mountainsides
Look up traditional mountain farming in Peru and Bolivia
expectedProcess: Student researches Andean terrace farming
Student learns about Quechua and other mountain peoples
Student discovers how terraces help grow food on slopes
Student understands traditional mountain agriculture
rounds.explainHtml:
Outstanding detective work! You found the Sacred Valley!

The Sacred Valley is where the Quechua people (descendants of the Incas) still live and farm the way their ancestors did hundreds of years ago. They cut terraces (steps) into the mountainsides to create flat places for growing potatoes, corn, and quinoa way up high in the mountains.

What You Learned:

  • People can live and farm in very high mountain areas
  • Terraces help farmers grow crops on steep mountain slopes
  • Indigenous people have special knowledge about mountain farming
  • Traditional ways of farming can be very smart and successful

rounds.clueHtml:
Mountain Detective Clue #4:

Dr. Altiplano has moved to her secret base! Our spy satellites found a sign that says 'ENVIRONMENTAL MONITORING STATION - ACONCAGUA.' Here's what we know:

  • She's hiding at the tallest mountain in both North and South America!
  • This mountain is so tall that mountain climbers have to spend weeks getting used to the thin air before they can reach the top
  • Even though it's super tall, you don't need ropes and special climbing gear - just really strong legs and lungs!
  • It's in a country that's shaped like a long, skinny piece of land

Your job: Find the tallest mountain in the Americas!
researchPrompts: Look up the highest mountain in South America
Research Aconcagua mountain height and location
Find which country Aconcagua is in
Look up what makes Aconcagua special for mountain climbers
expectedProcess: Student researches highest peaks in the Americas
Student finds that Aconcagua is the tallest
Student locates Aconcagua in Argentina
Student learns about high-altitude mountain climbing

reveal.note: Hides at places where it's hard to breathe

rounds.explainHtml:
Incredible detective skills! You found Aconcagua!

Aconcagua is 22,838 feet tall (almost 23,000 feet!). That makes it the highest mountain in both North and South America. It's in Argentina, near the border with Chile. Even though it's super tall, mountain climbers don't need ropes because it's not a rocky cliff - just a really, really high mountain that's hard to climb because the air is so thin.

What You Learned:

  • Aconcagua is the highest mountain in the Americas
  • Very high mountains make it hard to breathe because of thin air
  • Some tall mountains can be climbed without ropes
  • Argentina and Chile are long, skinny countries in South America

rounds.clueHtml:
FINAL Mountain Detective Clue:

We found Dr. Altiplano's secret plan! She's been setting up a classroom to teach kids about mountains and climate. Here's her final hideout:

  • She's in a place where she can see all the mountain peaks around her
  • Her classroom has maps showing how mountains affect weather all over the world
  • She wants to teach students that mountains are super important for our planet's climate
  • She thinks if kids learn about mountains, they'll want to protect them

Final Mission: You've followed Dr. Altiplano through her whole mountain adventure! Now put together everything you learned to find her exact hideout location!
researchPrompts: Think about all the mountain places you found
Research why mountains are important for climate
Look up how mountains affect weather patterns
Consider where Dr. Altiplano would want to teach about mountains
expectedProcess: Student reviews all previous clues and locations
Student connects mountain geography to climate
Student understands Dr. Altiplano's educational mission
Student identifies the final teaching location

reveal.trait: Wants to teach kids about mountain protection
reveal.note: Believes education can save the environment

rounds.explainHtml:
CASE SOLVED! You caught Dr. Altiplano at her mountain education center!

Dr. Altiplano wasn't really a bad person - she just cared so much about protecting mountains that she made some wrong choices. She was stealing equipment because she wanted to teach people how important mountains are for our planet. Mountains help control weather, provide fresh water, and are home to many special plants and animals.

What You Accomplished:

  • You learned to use maps and globes to find mountain ranges
  • You discovered how mountains affect climate and weather
  • You researched how people live and work in mountain areas
  • You understand why mountains are important to protect

Sourdough Pete says: 'Great mountain detective work! You learned that caring about the environment is good, but there are right ways and wrong ways to help. Dr. Altiplano should have worked with other scientists instead of stealing equipment!'
